name: Pickled Potatoes
description: What a treat to have a jar of these PIckled Potatoes in the fridge!  I used 3 jalapenos to give them some kick but you can always use less for a milder batch.  (Note: these instructions are not designed for long-term canning.)

recipeInstructions.text: A single large Gold potato is usually around a pound.  You can either cube a single potato for this recipe, or you can use two potatoes to get a pound worth of fry-style slivers.
recipeInstructions.name: A single large Gold potato is usually around a pound.  You can either cube a single potato for this recipe, or you can use two potatoes to get a pound worth of fry-style slivers.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the chopped potato to some boiling water and cook for a few minutes.   I give them just a quick swim to get a headstart on cooking, about 3-4 minutes.  Drain the potatoes and set them aside until you need them.
recipeInstructions.name: Add the chopped potato to some boiling water and cook for a few minutes.   I give them just a quick swim to get a headstart on cooking, about 3-4 minutes.  Drain the potatoes and set them aside until you need them.

recipeInstructions.text: Peel and roughly chop the 1/2 onion and 4 garlic cloves.
recipeInstructions.name: Peel and roughly chop the 1/2 onion and 4 garlic cloves.

recipeInstructions.text: Heat a glug of oil in a medium-sized saucepan over medium heat.  Saute the onion and garlic for a few minutes until the onion has softened.
recipeInstructions.name: Heat a glug of oil in a medium-sized saucepan over medium heat.  Saute the onion and garlic for a few minutes until the onion has softened.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the spices to the onion-garlic mixture:  1/4 teaspoon cumin seeds, 1/2 teaspoon Mexican oregano, 8-10 black peppercorns.  I usually give the spices a quick crush in the molcajete but this is optional.  And feel free to use powdered spices if you don't have seeds or peppercorns on hand.  Cook briefly.
recipeInstructions.name: Add the spices to the onion-garlic mixture:  1/4 teaspoon cumin seeds, 1/2 teaspoon Mexican oregano, 8-10 black peppercorns.  I usually give the spices a quick crush in the molcajete but this is optional.  And feel free to use powdered spices if you don't have seeds or peppercorns on hand.  Cook briefly.

recipeInstructions.text: Rinse and de-stem the jalapenos, chopping them up into coin-sized slices.  I used 3 jalapenos but you can always use less for a milder batch.   Add the sliced jalapenos and drained potatoes to the pan.  Cook briefly and then add the remaining ingredients:  1 tablespoon salt, 1.5 cups white vinegar,  and 1 cup water.
recipeInstructions.name: Rinse and de-stem the jalapenos, chopping them up into coin-sized slices.  I used 3 jalapenos but you can always use less for a milder batch.   Add the sliced jalapenos and drained potatoes to the pan.  Cook briefly and then add the remaining ingredients:  1 tablespoon salt, 1.5 cups white vinegar,  and 1 cup water.

recipeInstructions.text: Give it a good stir and bring this mixture up to a boil.  Once it's boiling you can transfer the mixture to a quart-sized Mason jar (or two pint-sized jars).  I usually use tongs to add the veggies to the jar and then pour the vinegar mixture all the way to the brim.  You can give the papas a taste test now for a preview, but they won't have full flavor until they rest overnight in the brine.

recipeInstructions.text: I usually let the jar cool on the counter for a bit, then cap and store it in the fridge where it will keep for weeks at a time.
